facts.text: Appellants convicted by Special Judge of Delhi under s.120B, s.224/109 IPC and s.5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, who were police companystables at the time of the occurrence, were companyvicted by the Special Judge of Delhi under s. 120B and s. 224/109 of the Indian Penal Code and s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act  2 of 1947 .

facts.text: Appellants sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment under s.5(2) POCA 1947 and nine months RI under each of s.120B and 224/109 IPC, to run concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: They were sentenced to two years rigorous imprisonment under s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and to nine months rigorous imprisonment under each of the ss. 120B and 224/109 of the Indian Penal Code. 1220 The sentences of imprisonment were directed to run companycurrently.

facts.text: Appeals to Punjab High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Their appeals to the Punjab High Court were dismissed and the present appeals are by special leave.

facts.text: Prosecution case: appellants conspired at Delhi with Ram Saran Das (approver), M.P. Khare, Nand Parkash Kapur and Murari between 6th and 16th November 1955 to bring about escape of M.P. Khare from lawful custody.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the prosecution, as stated in the charge, was that the appellants had companyspired at Delhi with Ram Saran Das, the approver, M. P. Khare, Nand Parkash Kapur and Murari between the 6th and 16th of November, 1955, to bring about the escape from lawful custody of M. P. Khare, an undertrial prisoner,

facts.text: M.P. Khare was an undertrial prisoner.

anchor.surface_text: to bring about the escape from lawful custody of M. P. Khare, an undertrial prisoner, and that they had also agreed to accept Rs. 1,000 each and other pecuniary advantages as illegal gratification

facts.text: Appellants agreed to accept Rs.1000 each and other pecuniary advantages as illegal gratification for escape.

anchor.surface_text: an undertrial prisoner, and that they had also agreed to accept Rs. 1,000 each and other pecuniary advantages as illegal gratification for rendering the escape of M. P. Khare from lawful custody and that in pursuance of the said companyspiracy

facts.text: In pursuance of conspiracy, appellants abetted escape of M.P. Khare and accepted illegal gratification from Nand Parkash Kapur.

anchor.surface_text: for rendering the escape of M. P. Khare from lawful custody and that in pursuance of the said companyspiracy they had abetted the escape of M. P. Khare and that they had accepted the illegal gratification from Nand Parkash Kapur.

facts.text: Courts below found M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody, appellants enabled him, and received money as illegal gratification.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the findings of the companyrts below that M.P. Khare escaped from lawful custody and the appellants had enabled him to do so and that they had received money as illegal gratification for the part they had played in enabling M.P. Khare to escape from lawful custody.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we are of the opinion that although the offence was triable exclusively by the Court of the Special Judge the District Magistrate had authority to tender a pardon under s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as the companyrt of the Special Judge was, in law, a Court of Session.

arguments.claim: The amendment to s.337 CrPC could have no application to a pardon tendered on 1-12-55

anchor.surface_text: The amendment to s. 337 of the 1224 Code, which came into effect in January, 1956, spoke of an offence punishable with imprisonment which may extend to seven years, but this amendment companyld have numberapplication to a pardon tendered on 1-12-55.

holdings.text: The District Magistrate had authority to tender a pardon under s. 337 CrPC as the Court of Special Judge was, in law, a Court of Session.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we are of the opinion that although the offence was triable exclusively by the Court of the Special Judge the District Magistrate had authority to tender a pardon under s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as the court of the Special Judge was, in law, a Court of Session.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.8(3) Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952 deems Special Judge a Court of Session for CrPC purposes; thus falls within s.337 CrPC scope for DM pardon; amendment post-pardon inapplicable.

holdings.text: Under s.8(3) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act 1952, the Court of Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session for purposes of CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 3  of the Criminal Law  Amendment  Act of 1952 it is expressly stated that for the purposes of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Court of Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session trying cases without a jury or without the aid of assessors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express textual deeming provision in CLAA s.8(3) applies to CrPC including s.337.

holdings.text: Conferment of pardon power on Special Judge under s.8(2) CLAA does not deprive District Magistrate of power under s.337 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 2  of the Criminal Law  Amend- ment  Act, 1952, the Special Judge has also been granted power to tender pardon. The conferment of this power on the Special Judge in no way deprives the District Magistrate of his power to grant a pardon under s. 337 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent jurisdiction as per CrPC ss.337 proviso, 338; power grant additional, not exclusive.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the submission that the District Magistrate had no authority to tender pardon to the approver and thus his evidence inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: There seems to us, therefore, no substance in the submission made that the District Magistrate had no authority to tender a pardon to Ram Saran Das, the approver, and consequently the approver's evidence was inadmissible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: DM had jurisdiction; approver examined post-pardon.

holdings.text: Prosecution witnesses Mela Ram (PW6) and Shiv Parshad (PW7) were not accomplices and their testimony could be considered.

anchor.surface_text: We have examined the evidence of Mela Ram and Shiv Parshad and find nothing in their evidence which establishes them as accomplices.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct examination of evidence shows no accomplice status; not urged before High Court; lower courts entitled to believe, no reason to differ.

holdings.text: Failure to hold test identification parade does not render court identification evidence inadmissible; weight is for courts of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prudent but not mandatory for admissibility; appellants known to police witnesses; no reassessment without exceptional grounds.

holdings.text: Irregularity in framing combined charge instead of separate under s.233 CrPC cured by s.537 CrPC as no prejudice caused.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the irregularity committed, in this case, was 1222 cured by the provisions of s. 537 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objection raised but abandoned before Special Judge; accused's counsel affirmed charge correct; not raised in High Court; no prejudice evident.

holdings.text: Sanction under s.196A CrPC for s.120B not considerable as question of fact not raised at trial or High Court; academic if POCA conviction affirmed.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a sanction had been granted under s. 196A 1223 was a question of fact which ought to have been urged at the trial and before the High Court. It is impossible at this stage to go into this question of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: not urged timely; academic given POCA conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we are of the opinion that although the offence was triable exclusively by the Court of the Special Judge the District Magistrate had authority to tender a pardon under s. 337 of the Code of Criminal Procedure as the court of the Special Judge was, in law, a Court of Session.

There seems to us, therefore, numbersubstance in the submission made that the District Magistrate had number authority to tender a pardon to Ram Saran Das, the approver, and companysequently the approvers evidence was inadmissible.

Under s. 8 3  of the Criminal Law  Amendment  Act of 1952 it is expressly stated that for the purposes of the provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Court of Special Judge shall be deemed to be a Court of Session trying cases without a jury or without the aid of assessors.

There seems to us, therefore, numbersubstance in the submission made that the District Magistrate had number authority to tender a pardon to Ram Saran Das, the approver, and companysequently the approvers evidence was inadmissible.

edges.explanation: h3's holding that CLAA s.8(2) does not deprive DM power supports h4's conclusion of no substance in the objection
h3 clarifies that Special Judge's pardon power under CLAA s.8(2) does not deprive DM's s.337 power, addressing i1

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 8 2  of the Criminal Law  Amend- ment  Act, 1952, the Special Judge has also been granted power to tender pardon. The conferment of this power on the Special Judge in no way deprives the District Magistrate of his power to grant a pardon under s. 337 of the Code.

There seems to us, therefore, numbersubstance in the submission made that the District Magistrate had number authority to tender a pardon to Ram Saran Das, the approver, and companysequently the approvers evidence was inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: There seems to us, therefore, no substance in the submission made that the District Magistrate had no authority to tender a pardon to Ram Saran Das, the approver, and consequently the approver's evidence was inadmissible.

There seems to us, therefore, numbersubstance in the submission made that the District Magistrate had number authority to tender a pardon to Ram Saran Das, the approver, and companysequently the approvers evidence was inadmissible.
We have examined the evidence of Mela Ram and Shiv Parshad and find nothing in their evidence which establishes them as accomplices.

There seems to us, therefore, numbersubstance in the submission made that the District Magistrate had number authority to tender a pardon to Ram Saran Das, the approver, and companysequently the approvers evidence was inadmissible.
